div.p: Court of Impeachment

State of Mississippi
vs
Adelbert Ames, Governor

Answer to
Articles of Impeachment
March 22, 1876
div.note: This is not a letter... should be titled something like "Mississippi Governor Adelbert Ames' Answers to Articles of Impeachment"

div.p: Before the Honorable the Senate of the State of Mississippi sitting as a high court of Impeachment
In the matter of the impeachment of Adelbert Ames, Governor of the State of Mississippi

The answer and pleas of Adel-bert Ames, Governor of the State of Mississippi, to the articles of impeach-ment exhibited against him in the said court by the Honorable the House of Representatives of the State of Mississippi in support of their impeachment against him for high crimes and misdemeanors supposed to have been committed by him.

This respondent comes into the said Court and, protesting that there is no high crime or misdemeanor par-ticularly alleged in the said articles of impeachment to which he is or can be bound by law to make answer; and saving to himself now and at all times hereafter all benefit of exception to the insufficiency of the said articles and each of them, and to the defects therein appearing in

in point of law or otherwise; and protesting also that he ought to not to be injured in any manner by any words or any want of form in this his answer; submits the fol-lowing by way of answer to the said articles
I

For answer to the first article your respondent says that true it is that in the beginning of the month of August, 1875, and soon after the third day of said month, he did receive from Joshua Stevens treasurer of Nox-ubee County, a letter a copy of which is embodied in the said first article; that said letter, as he now recollects, was either delivered to him personal-ly by J B Allgood, president of the Board of Supervisors of said Noxubee County, or he was soon after the receipt of said letter called upon in regard to the contents thereof by the said Allgood, who exhibit-ed then and there in his conversa-tion with this respondent great hos-tility toward W M. Conner, the fact being that the said Allgood and the said Conner were rival candidates for a nomination to the office of sheriff of Noxubee County, which nomi-
-nation was about to be made, in the month of September following and the election for which by the people was to take place in the be-ginning of the month of November following

Your respondent took the sub-ject of the said letter into considera-tion and resorted to proper meas-ures to inform himself of the facts in order that he might make up his mind as to his duty in the premises, and upon the examination he gave the sub-ject he became convinced that it was very probable if not en-tirely certain, and your respond-ent was then inclined to believe, and still does believe that the said Conner was not a defaulter to the County of Noxubee; and your respondent further as-certained that in due course of proceedings in said County the matter had been brought before the grand jury of said County for their action, and the said grand jury of the County had reported that the said Conner owed the County of Noxubee nothing
Your respondent further states that the Board of Supervisors

of said Noxubee County ordered suit to be brought against said Conner by a civil action in the Circuit Court of said Noxubee County returnable at the October term of said Court for said Coun-ty, which suit is still pending, as he is informed, and unde-cided.

And your respondent fur-ther states that a bill has been introduced into the Honorable the House of Representatives to au-thorize the Board of Supervisors of Noxubee County to employ some suitable person to take and state an account between the said Conner, a former tax-collector of said county, and the for-mer treasurer of said County, which bill was passed in said House of Representatives

And your respondent avers that in reference to the doings set forth and alleged in the said first article he acted to the best of his knowledge and ability, with the sole view of doing justice between the people of said Noxu-bee County and the said Conner and in fulfillment of his duty to the State.
II

And for answer to the sec-ond article, your respondent says that true it is that he did appoint the persons named in the said article to the offices therein named of justice of the peace and consta-ble in Washington County; but he says he was by law authoriz-ed so to do; that vacancies had occurred in the said offices which could not have been filled until notices of ^the delay^ required by law for notices of election from the proper officers had expired, unless he had made the said provisional appointments, which he made to the end that there should be such officers in existence under his provisional appointment dur-ing these delays; and that his action was based exclusively on what he considered his right and duty under the law and a just regard for the public wel-fare, and that in so doing he only followed the precedents which had been set in sim-ilar cases under the existing constitution and code of Mis-sissippi.
III

And for answer to the third article your respondent says that true it is that he did approve, as set forth in said article, the bond of M L Holland as state treasurer, but that he was not, at the time of said approval, and is not now aware that said bond was defective in form, and avers that said article does not point out any defect in the form of said bond; that as to the affida-vits of the sureties appended to said bond, they do not form any part of the same, and the duties of the Governor with respect to the form of the affidavit are merely di-rectory; that the affidavits are in the same form as those ap-pearing on the bonds approved for several years previous in the office of Governor of this State, and that he signed the approval without noticing the absence of the expression pointed out and complained of by said article and without any evil intention
And this respondent further answers that he believed then and still believes that the sureties on said bond were good and the

State perfectly secure, and that in point of fact no loss what-ever has accrued to the State by reason of said bond or the sureties thereon; and that the said treasurer M L Holland, on leaving the office settled in full with the State without any defalcation or loss to the State whatever And so he says that in this matter he discharged his duty to the State to the best of his knowledge and ability, and the State has received no harm
IV

And in answer to the fourth article, this respondent says that true it is that he did receive from the Attorney General the letter embodied in said article, but he denies that he had the right or that it was his duty, as averred in said article to suspend the treasurer, for the reason that no charge authorizing his sus-pension had been made against him, and this respondent had no reason to believe that any legal cause for suspension existed, and that he had no right to take possession of said office, and therefore did not do so, and knew that there was no cause for his doing so even if he had

such right, and for the reason that a short time previous to the date of said letter set out in said fourth article this respondent had appointed three persons, skillful account-ants to wit, J L Power C. A. Brougher and A. Virden, who were appointed on account of certain rumors with reference to the office of the treasurer, and they had reported that all the funds were there safe in the treasurer's hands and all the of-fice and its business in a satisfactory condition. The re-spondent denies that he was activated by any partisan purpose, but that he acted solely upon the discretion vested in him by law for the best interest of the State; and that the State has not lost one cent, as the term of the said treasurer has expired, and his accounts have been settled; that the official acts of the said treasurer were noted and binding as lawful official acts in regard to all persons interested or af-fected thereby
And your respondent fur-ther avers that on the receipt of the

letter of the Attorney General set out in said fourth article, he sent word to the said Holland and notified him of the objections of the At-torney General; that the sad Hol-land was at that time absent from the city, and his deputy John B Raymond informed this respondent that he would take measures to supply a new bond, averring, however, that the one already given was perfectly good; but the said treasurer neglected to renew the said bond during the remainder of his term of office [gap] And respondent further says that he was under the impression at the time that the securities on the bond were owners of freehold property as required by law, and he still believes that they were such
V

And this respondent, in answer to the fifth article, says that in the months of December, 1874, and Jan-uary, 1875, Peter Crosby, who had previously been legally elected sher-iff of the county of Warren, was legally entitled to the possession

of and to exercise all the powers, rights and duties of sheriff in said county, but had, by an illegal and overpowering armed force of men in said county been expelled from his office room, books, papers and all other official and public property of which he was legally in custody, and compelled by the said armed force of men to sign a paper purporting to be a resignation of his office of sheriff; that thereupon the Board of Super-visors of Warren County, erroneously supposing said office of sheriff to be vacant, did on the ninth and tenth days of December, 1874, illegal-ly order an election to fill the sup-posed and pretended vacancy in the office of sheriff of Warren County, to be held on the thirty first day of the same month of December, 1874; that on the twenty fourth day of the said month of December, 1874, the legislature passed an act to take ef-fect from and after its passage providing that in all cases of special elections to fill vacancies in county offices sixty days' notice of the election should be given, and that this provision should be applicable to all elections, as well those already ordered as to others;

that thereupon the said Board of Supervisors, on the twenty-ninth day of the same month of December, 1874, and in obedience to the above-recited act of the legis-lature, repealed and set aside the above-named orders of ninth and tenth December ordering an election of sheriff on the thirty-first of said month, and made no other order for an election. Nevertheless certain persons in War-ren County, not regarding the acts of the legislature and the resolu-tions of the Board of Supervisors, did, illegally, go through with some form of a pretended election on the thirty first day of December, 1874, and did illegally, in some form, declare and pretend that A J Flan-agan had been elected sheriff, and that the said Flanagan did thereupon pretend that he had been elected sheriff, and although he had been refused a recognition ^of his pretended quality of sheriff^ by the Board of Supervisors of War-ren County, he took, by som il-legal and forcible means, posses-sion of the office room's, books, papers, archives and public prop-erty of the office of sheriff, to the

illegal exclusion of Peter Crosby the legal sheriff, who alone was en-titled to them; that in pursuance of his duty to see the laws of this state faithfully executed, this re-spondent, being apprised of the ille-gal acts of the said Flanagan, did call upon General Emory commanding the United States Military Department of the Gulf, embracing this State, to give di-rection to the armed force of the United States under his com-mand to put the said A. J. Flanagan out of possession of the rooms and property il-legally possessed by him as above set forth, seeing that the said Flanagan was a naked tres-passer, without a shadow of legal right or color of author-ity; and the said General Emo-ry commanded Major Head of the thirteenth United States Infantry, stationed at Vicksburg, to put the said Flan-agan out of possession, which order Major Head duly executed; and this is the correct statement of the transaction described in the said fifth article
And this respondent fur-

-ther avers that the United States troops had been posted at Vicksburg under orders of the President of the United States, by virtue of the Constitution and laws thereof, and in compliance with a request made by the legislature of the State of Mis-sissippi, to suppress the vio-lence which then existed in the county of Warren, and to restore peace and order; and that the calling upon the arm-ed force of the United States under these circumstances, to put said Flanagan out of his pretended possession of the office of sheriff of Warren County was strictly in pursuance of the duties of respondent as Governor of the State
VI
And this respondent, in answer to the sixth article says that true it is that at the date of the contract al-leged in said sixth article, speci-

-fication first, a contract was in existence made between the Board of Inspectors of the Penitentiary and the firm of Powers and ^Charles S.^ Jobes which extended to the twenty seventh of April, 1875, which contract was for all the convicts then in the Pen-itentiary. The existence of this con-tract rendered it impossible for the inspectors to make any other con-tract than the one they did with French, as they assured this respond-ent at the time, and as he then believed and still does believe; that the act alleged in the specification of February 26th 1875, was passed through the legislature without any consultation between the re-spondent and the said French or between him and any other per-son whatsoever; and that he had no other knowledge of the passage of said act while passing through the legislature than is ordinarily received from the public prints or other public sources of in-formation; that inasmuch as the act of twenty-sixth of February, 1875, contemplated the employment of the convicts outside of the Penitentiary, there being no means of employing them inside

and not even cells enough to ac-commodate them, and there being no public works of the State on which they could be employed out-side, it was clear that the only employment they could be put to would be plantation work; but as no delivery could be made of the convicts to any one who should desire to employ them in such work before the expiration of the Powers & Jobe's contract on the 27th of April 1875, which would be too late for the purposes of planting, no other par-ties than those who held the Powers & Jobes contract could or would take them; that the Inspectors of the Peniten-tiary informed respondent that this was the best and only contract they could make by reason of the cir-cumstances just set forth; and that he, believing said information to be correct, as he does still believe, ap-proved the said contract

And the respondent further says, that had the contract not been approved, he was then of opinion, and still is, that the whole cost of keeping the said convicts in the Penitentiary for a year or thereabouts would have been thrown upon the State and entailed an expense upon it of forty or fifty thous-
-and dollars.

And this respondent further says, that he believed at the time, and still believes that the pendency of the act approved February 26th 1875, before the legislature, and that its probable and actual passage were well known and that any person able and willing to make an offer for the contract could have done so without any difficulty; and that he denies all charges of favoritism, connivance, consent, as-sistance and knowledge as charged against him in said specification

And this respondent further says, in answer to the second specifi-cation of said sixth article, that he de-nies that the contract therein mentioned of thirteenth of May was made by his connivance, consent and assistance, the truth being that he knew nothing with regard to said contract until after it had been completed between the said O C French and the Inspectors of the Penitentiary and when it was presented to him for his approval, at which time he was assured by the said In-spectors that it was the best con-tract under the circumstances they could possibly make; and the respond-ent, believing said assurances to be true, as he does now believe them,

and acting, as he then believed and still believes, for the best interests of the State, did approve said contract. And he further says that the act of 26th February, 1875, under which said contract was made, was then publicly known to the whole people of the State of Mississippi as a law of the State, and that any one who desired to contract for convict labor had full opportunity for so doing ^so^ as this respondent believed and does now verily believe.

And this respondent further says, in answer to the third specification of said sixth article, that he denies that the contract therein mentioned of 27th of February, 1875, between the said O C French and the Inspectors of the Penitentiary, was made with his con-sent, assistance and approval; that he knew nothing of said contract until it was presented to him for his appro-val; and that he did approve it under the circumstances and with the motives set forth already in his answer to the first and second specifications of said sixth article; that the sub-contract referred to in said specification between the said French & Jobes and Edward Richardson was a matter in regard to which he knew nothing at the time it was made,

as alleged in said third specification and was never brought to his knowledge officially until January of the following year, 1876, when he was requested by the said French to approve said sub-contract, who at the time informed him that such approval had been suggested by his counsel as a matter useful both to him and the sub-contractor Richard-son in their relations to the State con-vict labor; and that this respondent did affix his approval without any other design than that of obliging the said French and Richardson, and under the full belief, which he still entertains, that the interests of the State could not, and in point of fact were not, in any manner modified or compromised by his said act.

And in answer to the fourth specification of said sixth article, this respondent says that as to the contract therein mentioned of thir-teenth May, 1875, between said O. C French and the Inspectors of the Penitentiary, he denies that it was made with his consent, assistance and approval; that he knew no-thing of said contract until it was presented to him for his ap-proval, and that he did approve it under the circumstances and

with the motives set forth already in his answers to the first and second specifications of the said sixth article; that the sub-contract referred to in said fourth speci-fication between the said French & Jobes and Edward Richard-son was a matter with regard to which he knew nothing at the time it was made as alleged in said fourth specification, and was never brought to his know-ledge officially until January of the following year, 1876, when he was requested by the said French to approve said sub-contract, who at the time informed this respondent that such approval had been sug-gested by his counsel as a mat-ter useful both to him and the sub-contractor Richard-son in ^their^ relations to the State convict labor; and that this respondent did affix his approval without any other design than that of obliging the said French and Richardson, and under the full belief, which he still enter-tains, that the interests of the State could not, and in point of fact were not, in any manner modified
or compromised by his said action
VII

And in answer to the sev-enth article this respondent says, that he denies all and singular the allegations in said article con-tained charging and tending to charge him with conspiring to defame, slander and libel one G. Wiley Wells. This respond-ent admits that, having been informed by the said French, who voluntarily communicated the fact to this respondent without having been moved or interrogated there-unto by him, that attempts had been made by the said G. Wiley Wells or persons acting on his behalf, to bribe the said French as a member of the legislature of the State of Mississippi to vote for the said G Wiley Wells for the United States Senate, he did inquire as to the facts by a note ad-dressed to the said French, and that thereupon the said French did address to this respondent and he did receive the original of the let-ter a copy of which is embodied in the said seventh article. And this respondent denies that he

exerted any power or influence whatever to procure to be written to him the said letter by the said French, or that he made the writing of said letter a condition precedent to the signing of a contract alluded to in the said seventh article, or to his signing or approving the contracts bonds and papers referred to in the said seventh article. And this respondent denies that he used any influence whatever as gov-ernor to secure to French, Powers and Jobes the said convict labor of said State; and he avers that in all his acts and doings with regard to the said letter he violated no law of the State of Mississippi as alleged in said seventh article, that he did nothing but what he had a legal right to do, and acted solely with a view to what he believed to be, and still believes to be, the welfare of the people of the State of Mississippi
VIII

And in answer to the eighth article this respondent says that he admits that on the twelfth day of April, 1875, he did ap-point J B Deason to the office of chancellor of the nineteenth chancery district of this State, and that on the same day he did appoint Hiram Cassidy Junior, to the office of district attorney of said second judicial district of said State; but that before the said offices became vacant he had not been in-formed that either of the said parties desired to be appointed to the office to which they were respectively appointed as afore-said; and that after the resig-nations of the offices held pre-viously by said officials had been made, and when this respondent was deliberating as to how the vacancies should be filled, he was informed for the first time of what he had never known before, to wit, that the said Cassidy was will-ing to accept the office of district attorney, and the said Deason desired and was will-

-ing to accept the office of chancellor; believing at the time as he still does believe, that they were well qualified for the said offices respectively, and that their appoint-ment would be beneficial to the public interests, he did so appoint them, and has been informed and believes, and so states, that they have been efficient and faith-ful in the discharge of the duties of their respective offices, and that the State has been benefited by his said action; and that as to any arranegment between the said Cas-sidy and Deason for a swap or interchange of their offices made between them prior to their resignations, if it existed as is alleged, this respondent was at the time he received the said resignations and made the said appointments en-tirely ignorant.
IX

And your respondent further says, in answer to the ninth article, as well as to the thirteen specifications in said article contained that true it is he did appoint, as therein set forth, the chancellors therein named at the days and dates therein men-

tioned, and that the said appoint-ments were made in the vacation of the Senate, as therein alleged, and after the adjournment of the regular session of the legislature in the year 1874; but he says that the regular session of the State legislature in the year 1874 expired by adjournment on the sixth day of April of that year, and that none of the said chancellorships did expire before, in some cases about two and in others upwards of three months after the date of the said adjournment of the Senate; and as respondent then believed and still believes the Constitution and laws of this State do not mean that such an expiration of the term office of the chancellors comes within the mean-ing of the law directing the Governor to fill by appointment, with the ad-vice and consent of the Senate, offices when the term of the incum-bents is about to expire; and that he did believe, and does now be-lieve, that it was not his duty to make such nominations during the session of the Senate, as they would, in his judgment, then have been premature; but he did then believe, and does now believe, that it was

his right and duty to make the said appointments at the time he did; and that he denies emphatically that such appointments were made with the pur-poses and intents charged against him in the said article ninth and the speci-fications therein contained, but avers on the contrary that they were made, to the best of his judgment and belief, for the best interests of the State, and solely with the view of promoting those interests.
X

And in answer to article tenth this respondent says that he denies all and singular the allegations of corrupt intentions and effort to destroy the in-dependence of a portion of the judici-ary of the State, or make the same subservient to his will; and he denies that he endeavored to per-suade and induce E G Peyton, Chief Justice of the State, in such manner ^to interfere with^ direct and control, in such manner as should meet his, respondent's wishes the rulings, decisions and decrees of W B Peyton, then chancellor of the sixteenth district, in a certain cause then pending in the chancery court of Hinds county, as set forth in said tenth article.
XI

And in answer to article eleventh this respondent says that he did not report to the Senate at the session of 1875, the name of W B Peyton as chancellor of said sixteenth district for the reason that he was not bound by law so to do; but that in his judgment and view of the law as it then existed and does now exist, the appointment of W B Peyton as chancellor as set forth in said eleventh article, if not reported to the Senate within ten days of the commencement of its ses-sion, expired and became of no effect, and that it was entirely within the discretion of him, the respondent, not to send in the said Peyton's name, which he withheld for reasons sat-isfactory to his own mind, and founded solely on his judgment of the public interests at the time; and he denies each and every one of the allegations made against him in said eleventh article designed to show and charge upon him a corrupt and willful intent to degrade the judiciary of the State. And he further avers that he abstained from sending in the name of said W B Peyton to the Senate for considerations entirely disconnected from the decree of said

Peyton in the case of the University of Mississippi et al against the Vicks-burg & Nashville Railroad Company et al, but because the Attorney General of the State of Mississippi and W W Dedrick who appeared for the University report-ed to this respondent that the said Peyton had refused to place his rul-ings in the case in such shape upon the record as would enable the State to carry the case upon appeal to the Supreme Court, and had also treated them both with such indignity from the bench while they were con-ducting the cause as rendered it impossible for them to discharge their duty to the State and the University.
XII

And in answer to the twelfth article this respondent says that true it is that he did address to Honorable W A Drennan the letter dated February seventh, 1874, em-bodied in said twelfth article, for the reason that at that time the said Drennan was not entitled in law to hold the office of chancellor of the twelfth district which he was then occupying; that the said Dren-nan had, as stated in said twelfth

article, been appointed by R C Powers, then Governor of the State of Mississippi on the thirteenth day of September, 1873, but that his name had not been sent in to the Senate at the session of the same next after the said appointment, which session com-menced on the twentieth day of October, 1874, and that the appoint-ment of the said Drennan had consequently expired ten days after the commencement of the said ses-sion of the Senate; and that the letter embodied in the said twelfth article addressed to the said Dren-nan was designed simply to no-tify him that he was holding the office without authority of law and must cease so to do. And this respondent denies all alle-gations in said twelfth article con-tained charging or tending to charge him with illegal or cor-rupt intentions

And for further answer to said twelfth article this respondent says that he believed at the time and still does believe that the said W. A Drennan was incompetent to discharge the duties of the office of chancellor with profit to the State, and that he had acted arbitrarily
and illegally in the case of Morgan set forth in said article twelfth
XIII

And your respondent, in answer to the thirteenth article, says that he did revoke the appointment of Thomas Christian to the office of chancellor of the fourth chancery district, as stated in the letter signed by the re-spondent and addressed to the said Thomas Christian under date of July twenty-ninth, 1874, as contained in said thirteenth article; but that in performing said act he denies that he was prompted by any of the motives, intents or designs imputed to him in said thirteenth article, but only acted in pursuance of his consti-tutional right and sense of duty. This respondent says that, in pursuance of the powers vested in him by the Constitution of the State, he did on the twenty-third day of May, A D 1874 appoint as chancellor of the fourth district of the State John J Dennis to succeed the said Thomas Chris-tian, the then incumbent of the chan-cellorship of the said fourth district; that subsequently, having need to be absent from the State for a time, the Lieutenant Governor, A K Davis

assuming the position and powers of Governor as provided for in the Constitu-tion, did, by virtue of said powers, remove from the office of chan-cellor of said fourth district the said John J Dennis, by him, respondent so appointed as aforesaid, and ap-pointed in his stead the said Thomas Christian; that on his, respondent's, return to the State and finding that Chancellor Dennis by him appointed had been thus removed and the said Thomas Christian had been appointed, he, the respondent, not concurring in the wisdom and propriety of said removal and ap-pointment by virtue of the powers vested in him by the constitution, did remove from the chancellor-ship the said Thomas Christian and did reappoint the said John J Dennis on the twenty-ninth day of July, 1874; that the removals and appointments so made as aforesaid by this respondent were done in the vacation of the Senate of the State and in pursuance of the powers vested in him, the respondent by the Constitution and laws of the State, and in conformity with the opinion with regard to said constitution and laws expressed by Honorable G. E Harris
Attorney General of the State of Missis-sippi.
XIV.

And your respondent, in an-swer to the fourteenth article, says that by his letter dated July twenty-ninth, 1874, and embodied in the said fourteenth article, he did re-move J F Simmons from the office of chancellor of the tenth chancery dis-trict, but he denies that he did so with the intentions and motives imputed to him by the said fourteenth article, and avers that in making said removal he was acting solely within the powers conferred upon him by the constitution and laws of the State of Mississippi, and so acted with the intent of promoting, to the best of his judgment and ability, the best interests of the State; that he had, during a part of the summer of the year 1874, occasion to be ab-sent for a time from the State of Mississippi, and during his absence Lieutenant Governor A K Davis had assumed, in pursuance of the constitu-tion, the powers and duties of the office of Governor, and in the exer-cise of such powers the said A. K. Davis, Lieutenant Governor, had ap-

-pointed the said J F Simmons to be chancellor of the said tenth district, on the seventeenth ^day^ of July, 1874; that on the return of respondent to the State and resuming the powers and duties of Governor thereof, he removed the said J F Simmons, and on the tenth of October, 1874, he did appoint J M Campbell to be chancellor of said district, which appointment was made by him in virtue of the powers vested in him as Governor of the State by the Consti-tution and laws thereof, and was, in his judgment, a fit and proper appointment and one conducive to the interest of the State; and that his right to make such appoint-ment was sustained by the opinion of the Honorable G E Harris, Attorney General, as already stated by him in his answer to the thirteenth article
XV

And in answer to the fifteenth article this respondent says that he denies that in the appointments set out in the specifications to said fif-teenth article he acted with the in-tents, motives and purposes charged upon him in the said fifteenth arti-cle; on the contrary, he avers

that he acted with due judgment, con-sideration and discretion, and with no other design than to promote, to the best of his ability, the good of the ju-diciary establishment of the State and the welfare of the people. He denies that the persons appointed by him as set forth in the specifications to said fifteenth article were guilty of the crimes imputed to and charged upon them by the said fifteenth ar-ticle, and he denies that they were incompetent and unfitted to per-form the duties of the offices to which they were respectively ap-pointed

And this respondent further avers that by the constitution and laws of Mississippi, no class of persons is designated as the proper one from which chancellors are to be appointed, but that it is left to the sound discretion and judg-ment of the executive appointing power to select such persons as chancellors as he may deem com-petent and fit and proper to be appointed; that in the appoint-ments so made he conscientiously acted on that idea.
And with special reference to the first specification to said fifth Circuit

article, this respondent says that he did appoint J D Barton on the twenty-third of May, 1874, to be chancellor of the eighth district of the State, but he denies the intent and motives imputed to and charged upon him in said specification; and he denies that he, respondent, knew that the said Barton was wholly unworthy and incompetent to discharge the high duties of the office of chancellor by reason of the fact that he, the said Barton, was guilty of or publicly charged with the crime of forgery Respondent avers that he knew at the time of the appointment that the said Barton had been charged with the crime of forgery, but that he, the respondent carefully investigat-ed the charge and the proofs of-fered in support of it, and came to the conclusion that the charge was totally false and unfounded; and moreover that the charge so made against the said J D Barton had been fully investigated by the grand jury of Lee County, as this respondent was then informed, and that the said grand jury had refused to find a true bill against him. And this respondent further says that the said J D Barton was

recommended for appointment by a number of members of the bar prac-ticing in the said county of Lee; and thereupon, believing him to be hon-est and competent, he did appoint him and nominate him to the Senate, but, having reason to be-lieve that such opposition existed against him in the Senate that he could not be confirmed, this respondent withdrew the nomination.

And this respondent, answering, further to the second specification of said fifteenth article, says that he denies that at the time of the ap-pointment of the said J D Barton to the office of chancellor of the eighth district, he knew him to be wholly incompetent to discharge the duties of the office, but that he be-lieved and had good reason to believe at the time and does now believe that the said Barton had been for a long time a practitioner at the bar and had a good knowledge of his profession.

And in answer to the third specification of said article fifteenth this respondent says that he denies that at the time of the appointment of L C Abbott to be chancellor of the north district he knew him to

be wholly incompetent to perform the duties of the office. On the con-trary, this respondent was informed and believed at the time, and still does believe that the said Abbott was competent to perform the duties of chancellor; that he had been examined and admitted to the bar and declared duly qualified by the proper authority, and that since his appointment he has per-formed the duties of chancellor in a satisfactory manner

And in answer to the fourth specification of said fifteenth arti-cle, this respondent says that he denies that, at the time of the ap-pointment of William Breck to be chancellor of the thirteenth district, he knew him to be un-worthy and incompetent to dis-charge the duties of chancellor On the contrary, this respondent was informed and believed that that the said Breck had been duly admitted to practice law, had practiced honorably and success-fully for a great number of years, and that since his appoint-ment he has performed the du-ties of the office in a satisfac-tory manner.

And in answer to the fifth specification of said article fifteenth this respondent says that at the time of the appointment of said William Breck he carefully examined into the charge then made against the said Breck that, as assignee of one Graves (erroneously called Green in said fifth specification) in Madison County, he had defrauded and swindled the creditors of said estate, and had been a party to illegal and fraudu-lent contracts let out by the Board of Supervisors in Madison County in said State, as alleged in said fifth specification, and this respondent then came to the conclusion which he believed to be correct, and still does so believe, that the said Wil-liam Breck was entirely innocent of the charges then brought against him.

And in answer to the sixth specification of said article fifteenth this respondent says that he denies that at the time of the appointment of C Cullens to be chancellor of the eighth district this respondent knew him to be wholly unworthy and incompetent to discharge the duties of chancellor. On the con-trary, this respondent believed with
good reason, and still does believe, that he was entirely competent to discharge said duties, and under that belief appointed him.
XVI

And in answer to the six-teenth article this respondent says that he denies every allegation of said article tending to charge him with intending and contriving to provoke a conflict and collision with arms between the militia company therein spoken of and any of the other citizens of the State of Mississippi, and all allegations of whatever nature therein con-tained tending to charge him with the design of creating a riot or in any other respect of violating the laws of the State of Mississippi. He says that in direct-ing the militia company named in said article to march to Edwards Depot in the County of Hinds for the purpose of escorting a wagon-train of arms from the city of Jackson to said Edwards Depot, he was exercising the authority vested in him by the Constitution and laws of the state as commander-in-chief of the militia thereof, and was

acting, to the best of his judgment, and in good faith, with the sole view of preserving the peace and good order of said county and protecting the lives of the citizens thereof. And he further states that as soon as it became evident to him that peace and good order could be maintained without the assistance of the militia, and hav-ing received assurances to that effect from worthy and in-fluential citizens of the county of Hinds that by their efforts and influence peace and good order should be maintained, this respondent dismissed all the militia companies that had been called into service in said county and caused them to deliver their arms to proper places of deposit; and that in all the proceedings connected with the events set out in the said sixteenth article this respondent exercised no other powers than those confided by the constitution and laws to his judgment and discretion and with no other motive or in-tents than to maintain quiet and good order
XVII

And in answer to the sev-enteenth article and the specifications thereof this respondent says that on the third day of December, 1874 Peter Crosby, sheriff of Warren Coun-ty in this State, arrived in the city of Jackson and reported to this respondent that he had been as-sailed by a lawless body of armed men in the city of Vicksburg and compelled under fear of death to quit his office, and that under a like fear he had been forced to sign a resignation thereof, which, by reason of said duress, was null and void and of no effect; that in consequence of this alarm-ing report this respondent did in-vite to come to the executive mansion a number of respectable citizens some of whom were office-holders under the state government, in or-der to discuss the condition of affairs then existing in Warren County; that on the evening of that day there were present a number of persons, he thinks twenty or more, who had been invited as aforesaid and some of whom had come without special invitation; that during the evening there was a great

deal of conversation and a great many things were said, as would be likely to be said by persons of various character and temper, dis-cussing so grave an event. This respondent avers that the conversa-tion employed by him, whatever it may have been, and by the others who were present, was entirely of an unofficial character and can no more be considered as the foundation of a charge for crime or misdemeanor than the conver-sation of any other citizen exer-cising the right of free speech guar-anteed by the constitution to every citizen in the discussion of public affairs; that as to the language im-puted to him by the first spe-cification, this respondent thinks it quite possible that he may have used such a form of ex-pression, though he has not now any distinct recollection of having done so; but that if employed, it was not used with the intent charged upon him in said speci-fication, but merely a remark casually employed during a running conversation; and that as to the expression imputed to him in the second specification of said

seventeenth article, he avers that it is quite possible that he may have made use of such an expression, or used some words in that form, though he now has no distinct recollection of having done so; that the words charged are a com-mon and familiar quotation and in constant use, and that if used by him they were not employed with the intent imputed to him in said specification; and that as to the words charged against him in the third specification he avers that he has no recollec-tion of having employed any such language or anything of the same nature or import; that such language was entirely contrary to his principles and feelings, and he denies positively that he ever employed it.
XVIII

And in answer to the eight-eenth article this respondent says that he denies that on the third day of December, 1874, he made and delivered a certain intemperate and inflammatory speech and gave unlawful advice to Peter Crosby, which provoked and caused

a riot in the county of Warren a short time thereafter. Respondent says that on the occasion referred to in said eighteenth article Peter Crosby, Sheriff of Warren County having asked, in the course of the evening, what were his rights and duties in regard to regaining possession of the office from which he had been violently and illegally ejected, the Attorney General of the State, the Honorable G. E Harris, being present, read or caused to be read by some one standing near, from the Code of Mississippi of 1871, a section or part of a section defin-ing the rights and powers of sheriff in this State, as an answer to the question of the said Crosby, and that this respondent did then and there say nothing more to the said Crosby than that he should follow the advice of the Attorney General. And this respondent denies every allega-tion in said eighteenth article tend-ing to charge him with the design to disturb the peace and good or-der of the county of Warren or with any other illegal design or intent.
XIX

And in answer to the nine-teenth article this respondent denies that as therein charged, he did un-lawfully and corruptly advise Peter Crosby to organize without author-ity of law an armed body of men in Warren County to forcibly take possession of the office of sheriff of said county; that the only ad-vice and counsel which he gave to the said Crosby was, as has been already stated in respondent's answer to the eighteenth article, to the effect that he should act as advised by the attorney General of the State; and he denies all and every allegation of said nineteenth article tending to charge him with an in-tent and design to bring about riot, bloodshed and death or in any manner to violate the laws of the State of Mississippi.
XX

And in answer to the twentieth article, this respondent denies that he corruptly and unlawfully ad-vised Peter Crosby forcibly to take possession of the office of sheriff of the county of Warren; and he reiterates that the only advice

that he gave to the said Peter Crosby was as set forth in his answer to the eighteenth article, which was, to be guided by the opinion or an-swer given to him, as therein set forth, by the attorney General of the State; and he denies all the allega-tions in the said twentieth article tending to charge him with the intent and design of producing riot, bloodshed and death to the citizens of the county of Warren or in any way to violate the laws of the State of Mississippi
XXI

And in answer to the twenty-first article, this respondent says that Peter Crosby therein mentioned who had been legally elected sher-iff of the County of Warren in this State, was, previous to the said third day of December, 1874, exer-cising the duties and functions of the said office, when he, the said Crosby, reported to respondent that he had been dispossessed of his office and everything per-taining thereto by armed vio-lence, and compelled under fear of death to sign a resignation of his office; that this respondent
gave no other advice to the said Crosby than such as he has set forth in his answer to the eighteenth article, to act in pursuance of the opinion given to him by the attorney General of the State

And this respondent further says, that as said Crosby had been ejected from his office by vio-lence, there was and could have been no opposing authority ^legally^ in the actual peaceable possession of the said office and its outward insignia, but that all persons who had possession of said office to the exclusion of the said Crosby were acting against law. This respondent the denies that he gave any advice or counsel to the said Crosby designed or calculated to produce collision, riot, bloodshed and death, as charged against him in said twenty-first article, and denies every allegation therein contained tending to charge him with any violation, either in intent or act, of the laws of the State of Mississippi.

And this respondent, for further answer and plea to each and every one of the said articles of impeachment, says that they and no one of these charges against him any high crime and misde-meanor known and defined by the Constitution and laws of the State of Mississippi; and that only for such high crimes and misdemean-ors is he liable to impeach-ment; that impeachment is a criminal proceeding, and the punishment inflicted therefor a punishment for crime; and that any proceedings of this le-gislature inflicting any pun-ishment on him for the acts mentioned in the said articles of impeachment, inasmuch as such acts were not high crimes or misdemeanors by law at the time they were com-mitted, would be virtually and in effect an ex-post-facto law which is forbidden by the ninth section of the first article of the Constitution of Mississippi, and by the first paragraph; tenth section first article of the Constitution of the United States, of which Constitution he now claims the rights and privileges

And this respondent, for further answer and plea to each and everyone of the said articles of impeachment, says that in as much as no one of them charges him with any high crime and misdemeanor previously defined by the constitution and laws of the State of Mississippi, proceedings in the nature of an impeachment to find him guilty of such acts as crimes is virtually and in ef-fect to decree such now to be crimes by legislative enactment and at the same time to inflict punishment upon him judicially for having committed them; and that the consammation of such a proceeding would be and is virtually and in effect a bill of attainder and bill of pains and penalties, and as such is for-bidden to be enacted by the leg-islature of this State by the third ^first^ paragraph, tenth section, first ar-ticle of the constitution of the United States, which is the highest law of the land, anything in the constitution or laws of the State of Mississippi to the contrary notwithstanding; and he hereby invokes the rights and privileges under the said paragraph, sec-
-tion and article of the constitution of the United States.

And now, solemnly deny-ing again all the intentions and designs charged against him by the said articles of impeach-ment to violate an in any respect the constitution and laws of the State of Mississippi, and asserting that in all he did in the prem-ises, he was actuated only by a sense of what he deemed a high official duty, and were, as he believed and still confi-dently believes, well warranted and supported in every step by the constitution and laws of the State this respondent saith that he is not guilty of any high crime or misdemeanor as in said articles alleged, and this he prays may be inquired of by this honorable Court in such manner as law and justice may require.
